comments.commentBody: It only took one loss to the Red Sox for the Times to raise the specter of the Yankees missing the playoffs. This despite the fact that the Yankees clinching number is down to three. I'm a little curious as to whether or not the Times is mad with the playoff picture as it currently stands. Some people you like in third place?

Helps explain American voting habits. Vote against one's own basic
self interests in favor of attraction to an emotion-charged sound bite.
I'd like to eat more vegetables, but, with a few exceptions such as fresh ripe tomatoes, they taste yucky.

It's your life; eat what you want. Americans know what is and is not good for them.  They really don't need Washington to tell them. So get off our backs. Instead, cut our taxes by firing all the people who keep their jobs because they think they are absolutely neccessary when in reality they are really just a bunch of bureaucrats who don't give a damn about us but simply want to keep their usually well-paying jobs.

I know they're not all cool like an heirloom whatever... but what about frozen veg? Kept me healthy when I was a kid in the 70s and all you need is a microwave or a pot of boiling water for a couple minutes. People need to learn how to cook, or they'll be pretty much screwed for life. As a very good friend of mine once told me... "Ultimately, if you can't make dinner, you have nothing."

Come on, it's really all about money and special interest which equals big business. Do you really think it’s all about people not wanting to eat healthy? Look at the investment in junk food and compare it to healthy foods. There is no contest. Look at Coca Cola, Pepsi, mars bars, M&M's, fast food, etc. The list is huge. Big business would rather slowly poison the American consumer with their junk foods than to really help Americans eat healthy. Just add-up the Advertising budgets of big business who favors a junk food diet for America and for the world and compare it to all the ad money that is spent promoting healthy eating.

I think Michelle Obama has her finger on the issue, but there is no way in our life time that any meaningful effort will be put forth by big business to clean-up their poisonous promotion and selling of junk food to America and the world. Remember it’s all about money. Not health. After all isn’t that the American Way?
Eating healthy vs. making lots and lots and lots of money? What do you think?
It's very simple: unless cooking one's own (healthy) food is given a higher priority, we're unlikely to see any meaningful changes.

Wow, that's pretty sad. But I can see it. I've been a vegetarian for years but I hate salad too. And I hate when people say, "Oh, yes, there's something vegetarian--you can order the salad..." Ugh.

I will eat much of the same stuff in Vietnamese summer rolls though. There's a lot of great veg food options, but most of them aren't American originally.

In order to change an eating habit, conditions have to make it easiest to eat the "right stuff". This would translate into taxing all processed foods (sweetened beverages, snack foods, cereals - essentially, the food-like substances found in the middle aisles of the supermarket). Reduce corn, soybean and wheat subsidies, and instead, subsidize fruit and vegetable growers.

Remove the ridiculous food pyramid recommendations which, when followed, are very efficient livestock feedlot fattening strategies.

Instead, place grains and vegetable oil servings at the top - they should be the least eaten, followed by all forms of added sugar.

Reintroduce science-based food, nutrition and health/fitness classes as mandatory for grades K-12. Ban added sugar food products from public schools and public facilities.

Make the bad stuff expensive, accessible only within commercial stores (no vending machine access), ban advertising aimed at minors, and essentially treat these products like tobacco - health menaces which affect the public health.

Make fruits, vegetables, herbs and spices (the keys to making vegetables taste, look and smell enticing and desirable) inexpensive, easily obtainable and heavily commercially marketed.

Finally, when restaurants and food service operations are facing bottom line ingredient costs, they will become very creative in their use and presentation of vegetables in soups, main dishes, gratins, sides, etc. when those become the default most economical.

Historically, Americans didn't eat added sugar/ processed carbohydrate foodstuffs continually until the widespread introduction of fast foods, high fructose corn syrup and heavily subsidized grains production. Not coincidentally, this parallels the rise in US obesity, heart disease and diabetes rates.

One could say that it's hard earned US tax dollars at work increasing chronic disease and mortality.

I keep looking at my drivers license. It says I'm 67. I guess I'm old enough not to have to be told what to do!!

Buzz off!!

Kurt

Cooking advices that make vegetables more delicious would have been more effective than this campaign. Chewing raw carrots and celery is not pleasant for most people. And salads are not much better either.

Asian dishes have a lot of vegetables, but they are cooked to taste good, even to Westerners' taste buds. Maybe teaching Japanese or Chinese recipes to Americans is the way to go.

It's interesting to watch children change their eating habits during their formative years. I can remember my child eating up everything green and red and yellow in from of them. When they were a baby and up through about the age of 10 or 11.

Then it all went out the window. All that love for vegetables was replaced with a love for carbs, as this article attests to the main carb, the potato. And don't forget bread. Lots of both.

I can barely get a salad of any kind into them now, what a shame that they'll miss out on the lovely freshness of those colored foodstuffs that come from the ground!

Hasn't anyone ever heard of frozen vegetables?  You don't have to worry about them "going bad" and they probably don't cost a lot more than fresh vegetables.  It's certainly not the same as eating fresh vegetables, but it's tremendously better than *foregoing* vegetables.  I do *not* cook (my motto has always been "life's too short...."), but a typical dinner for me is a bag of frozen vegetables topped with a source of protein (either a can of sardines in water, a can of tuna in water, or a can of red kidney beans).  It's incredibly filling, very healthy, and it only requires a microwave & a can opener.  I also consume lots of water throughout the day and I never drink sodas, although I confess to drinking a large mug of really strong coffee every day.
Who the heck is surprised? Kids learn at school that fries count as a vegetable. Despite Jamie Oliver, our school still serves up pizza with fries on the side every day.

Nice to see soccer games on the times....but where are the most important games of all...Spanish league or La Liga ..... Remeber these big teams....Madrid, Barcelona, Valencia or Sevilla for example...Keep on going!!!!!!!
And the funny thing is the fans will watch no matter what time they play. (Fernando included!)

When you think there cannot be anymore cruelty or hatefulness or carelessness in American politics, just check up on what Tom Coburn & Jim DeMint are doing. They spend their time thinking up new ways to be villainous. Coburn, of course, prides himself on being "Dr. No," & DeMint prides himself on being Jim DeMint.

You would think, though, that even these bad men would realize that about half of the people who voted for them were women, & it would be good not to alienate half their voters, especially in an election year. But these guys also know this: the ladies who elect them pay absolutely no attention to what they do in Washington. I do not forgive the people of Oklahoma & South Carolina for sending these nasty little men to Washington. DeMint & Coburn are execrable, but they did not appoint themselves to represent us.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com
Demint has no power.  The Democrats control everything. The last I read they are supposed to be adults capable of accountability. Put the blame where is rightfully belongs.

Your article mentions that Washington has a Newseum. In honor of Senator Coburn and his friends, I propose a Nauseum, dedicated to the many ways our Senators make us feel sick to our stomachs.

While this sorry bunch of miscreants are slithering back to their home states rather than have an honest class war about not taxing their billionaire friends, there's another piece of legislation moldering in the massive pile. First Lady Michelle Obama's pet project to fight childhood obesity is stalled. Some Senators, and they know who they are, are worried that kids eating healthy might also be eating into the deficit. This cannot be allowed. So the smart deficit hawks are proposing we take the money AWAY from the Food Stamp Program to bring fresh fruits and veggies into school lunchrooms. How clever is that? Only, some spoilsports are crying foul: you can't rob from the poor to give to the poor.

Maybe you can convince Meryl Streep to testify before Congress when she comes back. She can stay in her Margaret Thatcher character, and she'll bring back such fond memories of Uncle Ronnie the Republicans will slobber and swoon and give her whatever she wants. Including the Women's History Museum.

"The answer — and people, how many times have you heard this story? — is that two senators, Jim DeMint of South Carolina and Tom Coburn of Oklahoma, have put holds on the bill. A hold is one of those quaint Senate traditions that ensures that each individual member of the chamber will have the power to bring all activity to a screeching and permanent halt"

It would be interesting to see a big piece of investigative journalism on this indefensible and despicable practice of individual holds. At least filibusters get somewhat played out in the light of day, but these holds seem to be very anonymous and very insidious.

It would be one thing if this involved the commitment of billions of federal dollars, but simply to expedite a private sector project would seem to be quite in line with southern conservative tea party goals. I wonder which voters Coburn and DeMint are expecting to impress. Or is this just another example of wanting to shut down all progress and freeze government action in its tracks.

If control of the House passes to the hands of the far right candidates who are running under the Republican banner, this will be the mildest of the stupidities. We will also see dismantling of progress in health reform, financial regulation, social security, medicare, national parks, infrastructure repair and everything else that the country needs.

I hope this piece of yours, Gail, puts enough pressure on these senators to remove their holds. And I hope to see a more comprehensive analysis of similar stupidies and injustices...

Let's look at the facts.

National Women's History Museum. Now can you think of four things far right extremists like DeMint find more unappealing? They have proven often enough that anything that has "national" connected to it must be bad because it might interfere with states' rights. You know, the same old tired canard they'll be using to try to take health care away from the poor and force millions of middle class Americans into penury because they will be back to having no coverage and no protection against the insurance industry buzzards.

Second and third, when have you known any right-winger to be concerned about either women or history, never mind women's history? Women are second class citizens to the right and as for history, well, George Bush and Dick Cheney showed the world the dazzling disdain the right has for that field of study.

Finally, museums, unless they're gun museums, or far-right religious theme park sorts of things, like the one we have here in Kentucky that "proves" that the world is only about 6,000 years old, because, well, you know, the Bible says so.

Maybe DeMint and Coburn have something much more surprising in mind. After all, Coburn was so concerned with "inalienable rights" when grilling Elena Kagan, perhaps they plan on pulling a Glenn Beck so that they can "take back" women's rights for themselves the way Beck wanted so much to restore civil rights, albeit for white rightwingers.

Yeah, I'm sure that's the idea. Because guys like DeMint and don't have enough rights already. They might as well claim women's rights for themselves. Then they won't need a museum, will they?

It is really surprising that two denizens of freedom and small government turn their backs on free enterprise and use the singular power and weight of the entire national government assigned to them to put a celebration of freedom on hold?

There are major subtexts here. (And a chance for parody!) Clearly, Sen. Coburn's office is engaged in a high level of paranoia, is bunkered against citizen conspiracies that threaten the social order and shows a wee bit of obsession.
Which government employee took how many “man” hours to assemble a list that has little in common except women are the namesakes, donors, or participants of the list's focused activity? Have women morphed into the old cliché once applied to blacks, they all are the same when it comes to honoring their achievements? (Who remembers that President Ford once thought his black Transportation secretary was a servant?) Why the fear of imaginary fund requests? Is this a delusion? Hasn't the Senator, as demonstrated by his present action, mastered the art of just say no?

Why not simply say every birth certificate issued for a female birth in the US is official recognition of the life and contributions of women - even while holding up the idea to review the 14th amendment’s right to birthright citizenship for women born to women in America under its explicit protections?

Does Jim DeMint have bonafides with Sarah Palin? Does she approve this? Has she been sent a message via twitter?

Have we seen the birth certificates for these two senators? Does anyone else see their sleath actions as an attempt to topple this country created by mothers? Are not their actions “outside of our comprehension?”
--Walter Rhett

Thanks for again speaking truth to power, Bob.  Technically , the recession might be over, but the Obama-depression is just picking up steam.  Obama is having the truth disguised until  after the elections, but people know.  This is the worst economic period since the 1960s and everything that Congress and Obama do makes it worse.

comments.commentBody:
Right you are that, “It’s sometimes hard to see” the national pain.

Right you are about, “the craziness and ugliness stirred up by the professional exploiters.”

But there’s one (slow, gradual) solution.

Many who read here are teachers – and teachers on their own can do something key simply by rapport with friends in the same school. Whatever subject, a teacher in one class can ask kids to write little bits of all sorts – and reference it by whatever may fit from the other subject.

The value for this is that teachers – any two – can teach kids that facts, truth, evidence all oblige some discipline. You can’t just invent things as do Republicans, the corporate monied, and their scripted, boughten politicians and tea-baggers – you can’t just shout buzz words and your own emotional immaturities as if reference to fantasy alone suffices.

I don’t have to remind any here how the apologists for U.S. militarism spread that without any reference to the originating provocations from Corporate America & CIA policies abroad that made so many enemies. I don’t need to remind any how U.S. high finance gamed its recklessness without any reference to anything but its own biz-&-law-school-learned scheming. No need to remind anyone that U.S. health care runs its for-profit-only biz without reference to the tens of millions outside it – or that Industrial Ag fuels its petroleum, chemical, and corn-syrup-based schemes without any regard for the rural, community cultures these have killed across America, and now the world. Corporate America can sink to its sociopathy because no one in it ever learned any arts of connections freeing any from their silo culture.

Teachers as individuals can, however, free and be more free. Just by linking with a fellow teacher or two, they can open the joys, literacy, and ethics of reference – wider linking other fields, culture, human beings.

We can start to be freed from what you so correctly call inabilities to see.

Millions upon millions of children will grow up as a permanent underclass. Millions more will settle for less. This is not the Democracy that we were promised. We are regressing back to the ancient Athenian form of Democracy: only the rich guys matter. It did not last long.
